bioghist.head: Thomas Leiper Kane (1822-1883)
bioghist.p: Thomas Leiper Kane was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, on January 27, 1822. He was educated in Philadelphia and, as a young man, traveled to Europe. For some years, he resided at Paris. After returning to Philadelphia, Kane studied law and was admitted to the bar in 1846. In that year, Kane visited Nauvoo and the Mormon camp at Council Bluffs. Although apparently never a Mormon himself, Kane was sympathetic to the Mormons and became a friend of Brigham Young. As a result, in 1858, Kane visited Salt Lake City with special instructions from President Buchanan and was instrumental in preventing a clash between the army and the Mormons. Kane served with distinction in the Civil War, retiring in 1863 with the rank of major-general. After his retirement, Kane resided in Pennsylvania and worked for a number of charitable causes. He died in Philadelphia in 1883.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Thomas Leiper Kane Papers consist of reports, drafts of speeches, and letters by Colonel Thomas Leiper Kane, as well as letters written to him. The latter are chiefly by the leaders of the Mormon Church and describe conditions in Utah and the relations between federal officials, the army, and the Mormons.

The papers are arranged chronologically and are accompanied by a copy of
The Collector , December 1944-January 1945, which contains a description of the Haiken Benjamin collection of Kane manuscripts offered for sale by Mary A. Benjamin. The remaining items are from the collection of the late Guido Bruno.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections [as they are acquired], and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

This finding aid, created before the advent of computer-generated files, has been converted into a ASCII data file by means of scanning and Optical Character Recognition software. While attempts have been made to retain the complete information from the original document a number of format changes have been made to present the structure of this archive in accordance with current practice.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Papers and correspondence relating to the Mormons. [1846 ?]-1853, 1856-1860, 1884. With copies of The Mormons and The Private Papers of Thomas Leiper Kane .

Colonel Kane became interested in the Mormons in 1846 when he visited Nauvoo and the Mormon camp at Council Bluffs. In 1858 he visited Salt Lake City with special instructions from President Buchanan and was instrumental in preventing a clash between the army and the Mormons.

The papers consist of reports, drafts of speeches and letters by Colonel Kane; and letters to him written chiefly by the leaders of the Mormon Church describing conditions in Utah and the relations between the federal officials and the army and the Mormons.
